A.clue: A sensor that measures acceleration forces, commonly used in mobile devices to detect orientation or motion
A networking hardware device that allows wireless-capable devices to connect to a wired network
The design of products, environments, and services to be accessible to people with disabilities, including compatibility with assistive technologies
A now-deprecated Microsoft software framework based on COM/OLE, used for embedding content like videos or calendars in applications
A unique reference to a specific location in memory used by software and hardware
A procedure used for solving a problem or performing a computation, consisting of a finite sequence of well-defined instructions
An alternate name or label that refers to another identifier in computing, often used for shortcuts or simplification
A type of computer that uses continuously varying physical phenomena (like voltages or mechanical motion) to model problems
A mobile operating system developed by Google, primarily for touchscreen devices
A set of rules and specifications that allows one software application to interact with another
A software program, especially on mobile devices, that performs a specific task for a user
Software designed to perform specific functions directly for an end user, like word processors or media players
A file or collection of files stored together, often compressed, for backup or transport
A data structure consisting of a collection of elements, each identified by an index or key, stored in contiguous memory
The field of computing focused on creating systems that simulate human intelligence, including learning and problem-solving
A motherboard and power-supply form factor specification introduced by Intel in 1995 for standardized PC design

B.clue: A copy of computer data stored elsewhere to restore the original after data loss or corruption
The maximum rate of data transfer across a network connection, typically measured in bits per second
A numbering system using only two digits, 0 and 1, fundamental to all digital computing
The smallest unit of data in computing, representing a single binary value (0 or 1)
A map of bits that defines a digital image, where each pixel's color is stored as binary data
A decentralized ledger of blocks linked using cryptography, often used to record transactions securely
A frequently updated website displaying posts in reverse chronological order, often for commentary or news
A wireless technology standard for short-range data exchange between devices using radio signals
The process of loading an operating system into a computer's memory upon startup or restart
A high-speed always-on internet connection using multiple channels to transmit data simultaneously
A software application used to access and navigate websites on the internet
An error, flaw or fault in software or hardware that causes it to produce incorrect or unexpected results
A communication system within a computer that transfers data between components like CPU and memory
A unit of digital information consisting of 8 bits, capable of encoding 256 values

C.clue: Hardware or software component that temporarily stores data so future requests for that data can be served faster
A toggle key on keyboards that, when activated, causes letters to be typed in uppercase until pressed again
A challenge-response test used to determine whether the user is human, helping prevent automated bots
Software that accesses services provided by a server over a network
A temporary storage area in memory used to hold data that has been copied or cut, allowing it to be pasted elsewhere
Delivery of computing services—like servers, storage, and software—over the internet on a pay-as-you-go basis
An instruction entered by a user to direct a computer or software program to perform a specific task
The act of running source code through a compiler to produce executable or machine code
A program that translates high-level source code into low-level machine code, bytecode, or another language
Process of reducing the size of data for storage or transmission by encoding it more efficiently
An electronic machine designed to process data according to a set of instructions, capable of running software
A small piece of data sent by a website to a browser to remember information about a user's session
Practice of protecting systems, networks, and programs from digital attacks
Illegal activity involving computers or networks, such as hacking, identity theft, or distributing malware

D.clue: A background process that runs independently of user control, often providing services to other programs
A graphical interface in computing that provides at-a-glance views of key metrics and data in one place
Raw facts or symbols that computers can process, like numbers, text, or observations
The process of analyzing large datasets to identify patterns and extract useful insights
An organized collection of structured information stored electronically, managed via a DBMS
The systematic process of detecting, isolating, and fixing errors in software
To restore a compressed file or data back to its original size or form
To remove data from a storage medium or file system
A personal computer designed for individual use, featuring a graphical desktop interface
Any data represented in discrete, binary form (0 and 1) rather than continuous analog signals
A storage medium where data is written magnetically on spinning platters
A hierarchical system translating human-readable domain names into IP addresses
A platform that uses OS-level virtualization to deliver software in containers
A digital file that contains text, images, or other data, created for viewing or printing
The process of receiving files from a remote system to your device
Software that enables an operating system to communicate with hardware devices
Digital rights management: technology used to control access to copyrighted digital content
Digital Subscriber Line: a broadband communications technology using telephone lines

E.clue: A method of exchanging digital messages between people via computer networks
A small digital pictogram used in electronic communication to convey expression or ideas
Software or hardware that imitates another computer system so programs designed for it can run
The process of transforming information into a coded form so only authorized parties can access it
Enterprise Resource Planning: integrated software for managing core business processes across departments
A widely used wired networking technology for connecting devices in LANs
A unit of digital information equal to one quintillion bytes (10¹⁸ bytes)
A file containing machine code that can be directly run by a computer's operating system

F.clue: Frequently Asked Questions: a list of common questions and answers on a specific topic
A named collection of data stored on a computer system, such as a document, image, or program
A network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on rules
Permanent software programmed into a hardware device's read-only memory, controlling its basic functions
A magnetic storage medium that uses rotating disks to hold digital data, popular before USB drives
A reusable set of libraries or tools that provides structure and common functionality to build software applications
Software that is provided to users free of charge, often with limited features or without source code
File Transfer Protocol: a standard network protocol used to transfer files between client and server

G.clue: Graphics Interchange Format: a bitmap image format that supports animation and transparency
A unit of digital information equal to one billion bytes (10⁹ bytes)
A distributed version control system commonly used for tracking changes in source code during development
Global Positioning System: a satellite-based navigation system providing location and time information
Visual elements on a screen such as images, shapes, and text used to present information or create interfaces
Graphical User Interface: a type of interface that allows users to interact with software visually using icons and windows

H.clue: To gain unauthorized access to computer systems or networks, often by exploiting vulnerabilities
A person skilled in computing and networking who may use this knowledge to solve problems or exploit systems
The physical components of a computer system like CPU, RAM, motherboard, and peripherals
A high-definition interface standard for transmitting uncompressed video and audio between devices
The standard markup language for creating and structuring web pages
A link in a document or on a web page that leads to another location when clicked
Text displayed on a web page that contains clickable links, forming a non-linear structure

I.clue: A small image or symbol used in user interfaces to represent actions, files, or programs
Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers: a global association that sets technical standards
A whole number (no fractions) that can be positive, negative, or zero
A shared boundary between two systems or components that enables them to communicate
The global network that connects computers and devices worldwide using standard protocols
Apple's mobile operating system designed for iPhone, iPad, and iPod Touch devices
A unique numerical label assigned to each device connected to a computer network that uses the Internet Protocol
The act of repeating a sequence of instructions or steps in a program, typically using loops

J.clue: A widely used, platform-independent programming language known for its portability
A scripting language primarily used to create and manage dynamic content on websites
A handheld input device used to control movement in games and simulations
A commonly used image format that compresses photographic content efficiently
Unwanted, unsolicited email messages sent in bulk, often for advertising or phishing

K.clue: The central core of an operating system that controls hardware, manages processes, memory, and facilitates communication between software and devices
A physical or virtual key used to encrypt/decrypt data or unlock functionality
The set of keys with letters, numbers, and symbols used to input data into a computer
A significant word or phrase used to categorize or trigger a function in programming or search

L.clue: Local Area Network: a network connecting devices within a limited area like a home or office
A portable personal computer with integrated screen, keyboard, and battery
A printer that uses a laser and electrically charged toner to produce high-quality text and graphics
A reference or pointer, usually clickable, that connects one document or location to another
An open-source Unix-like operating system kernel created by Linus Torvalds and community contributors
The use of reasoning principles to perform computation or solve problems in software
A wireless communication standard for high-speed data over mobile networks

M.clue: A family of personal computers designed and sold by Apple in the 1980s and '90s
A set of instructions that automate tasks in programs like spreadsheets or Word macros
A large, powerful computer used primarily by large organizations for bulk data processing
Malicious software designed to harm or exploit computer systems
The physical hardware in a computer used to store data temporarily or permanently, like RAM or hard drives
A device that modulates and demodulates signals for data transmission over telephone or cable lines
An output device that displays visual information on a screen, like text, images, or video
The main printed circuit board in a computer which houses the CPU, memory, and important connectors
A standard for encoding video and audio, commonly used for DVDs and online streaming
The combination of text, images, video, and audio in a single presentation or application

N.clue: A network of interconnected devices that share data and resources
A single computing device or system connected to a network
A portable computer similar to a laptop but even more compact

O.clue: Optical Character Recognition: technology that converts different types of documents into editable and searchable data
Software whose source code is available for anyone to view, modify, and distribute
A selectable choice in a program or menu that enables users to customize actions or features
The result produced by a computer program after processing input data

P.clue: A secret string of characters used to authenticate a user and authorize access to systems or data
To insert previously copied or cut content from the clipboard into a document or field
A type of cyber attack that uses deceptive communications to trick people into revealing sensitive information
A base set of technologies or tools on which applications are built and run, like mobile or cloud platforms
A software component that adds specific capabilities or features to an existing application
A website or gateway that provides access to a variety of services or information in one place
The central unit in a computer that executes instructions and processes data
Defined rules and formats that enable two or more devices or programs to communicate
A high-level, interpreted programming language known for its ease of use and readability

Q.clue: A two-dimensional barcode that stores information which can be scanned by devices like smartphones
Computing that uses quantum-mechanical phenomena like superposition and entanglement to perform operations
A data structure in which elements wait in line for processing, following First-In-First-Out order
The standard keyboard layout for Latin alphabet typewriters and PCs, named from its first six letters

R.clue: Volatile memory that can be accessed randomly and is used by the CPU to store temporary data
The process of restarting a computer by shutting down and starting it again
A system database in Windows that stores low-level settings for the OS and installed applications
Accessing a computer or network from a remote location, often over the internet
Read-Only Memory: non-volatile memory containing essential system firmware or BIOS
Gaining privileged control of a device, often by exploiting security vulnerabilities

S.clue: A special startup mode where only essential system components are loaded to diagnose issues
A computer or program that provides services or resources to other computers, known as clients
Computer programs that perform specific tasks on a device, as opposed to hardware or firmware
Unsolicited and often unwanted email, typically sent in bulk for advertising or malicious purposes
Structured Query Language: a standard programming language for managing and querying relational databases
Solid-State Drive: a storage device that uses flash memory and has no moving parts
Service Set Identifier: the name assigned to a Wi-Fi network to uniquely identify it
Secure Sockets Layer: an encryption protocol that ensures privacy and integrity of data transmitted over networks
Scalable Vector Graphics: an XML-based format for two-dimensional vector images

T.clue: A predefined file used as a starting point for creating new documents, designs, or code
A sequence of instructions within a process that can be scheduled independently by the OS
The creation and management of threads within a process to allow parallel execution
Temporary storage for deleted files, allowing recovery before permanent removal

U.clue: Running a processor at a clock speed lower than its default to reduce heat or power use
A family of multitasking, multi-user operating systems originating from AT&T's original in 1969
Uniform Resource Locator: the web address used to locate and access resources on the Internet
Universal Serial Bus: a standard interface for data and power between computers and peripherals

V.clue: Computer graphics composed of geometric shapes—points, lines, and curves—that can scale without loss
Video Graphics Array: a legacy display standard introduced by IBM in 1987
Real-time audio and video communications between remote participants (video calls/conferencing)
Malicious software that replicates by modifying other programs and spreading to other systems
Voice over Internet Protocol: technology for delivering voice communications via IP networks

W.clue: Wide Area Network: a telecommunications network that spans a broad geographic area
A single document or page on the web that is part of a broader website
A collection of related web pages, typically under a single domain, accessible via the Internet
A collaborative online encyclopedia that can be edited by its users
A Microsoft operating system featuring a graphical user interface and broad application support
A wireless networking technology based on IEEE 802.11 enabling devices to connect without cables
The global system of interlinked hypertext documents accessed via the Internet

X.clue: eXtensible Markup Language: a flexible format for creating structured data representations

Y.clue: A video platform where users can upload, share, and view videos

Z.clue: An exploit that takes advantage of a software vulnerability before a patch is available
A compressed archive file format (e.g., .zip) used to bundle and compress multiple files
